abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
<jats:title>Background</jats:title>
<jats:p>Coronaviruses (CoV) are a large family of viruses that are common in humans and many animal species. Animal coronaviruses rarely infect humans with the exceptions of the Middle East respiratory syndrome (<jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/mers/index.html">MERS-CoV</jats:ext-link>), the severe acute respiratory syndrome corona virus (SARS-CoV), and now SARS-CoV-2, which is the cause of the ongoing pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Several studies suggested that genetic variants in the <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> gene may influence the host susceptibility or resistance to SARS-CoV-2 infection according to the functional role of ACE2 in human pathophysiology. However, many of these studies have been conducted in silico based on epidemiological and population data. We therefore investigated the occurrence of <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> variants in a cohort of 131 Italian unrelated individuals clinically diagnosed with COVID-19 and in an Italian control population, to evaluate a possible allelic association with COVID-19, by direct DNA analysis.</jats:p>
</jats:sec><jats:sec>
<jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
<jats:p>As a pilot study, we analyzed, by whole-exome sequencing, genetic variants of <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> gene in 131 DNA samples of COVID-19 patients hospitalized at Tor Vergata University Hospital and at Bambino Gesù Children’s Hospital, Rome. We used a large control group consisting of 1000 individuals (500 males and 500 females).</jats:p>
</jats:sec><jats:sec>
<jats:title>Results</jats:title>
<jats:p>We identified three different germline variants: one intronic c.439+4G>A and two missense c.1888G>C p.(Asp630His) and c.2158A>G p.(Asn720Asp) in a total of 131 patients with a similar frequency in male and female. Thus far, only the c.1888G>C p.(Asp630His) variant shows a statistically different frequency compared to the ethnically matched populations. Therefore, further studies are needed in larger cohorts, since it was found only in one heterozygous COVID-19 patient.</jats:p>
</jats:sec><jats:sec>
<jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
<jats:p>Our results suggest that there is no strong evidence, in our cohort, of consistent association of <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> variants with COVID-19 severity. We might speculate that rare susceptibility/resistant alleles could be located in the non-coding regions of the <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> gene, known to play a role in regulation of the gene activity.</jats:p>
</jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Biological samples enrolled in the study were collected according to the ethical procedures of the GEFACOVID2.0 research program promoted by the University of Rome Tor Vergata. This program will ensure that its work is carried out with the highest regard for ethical issues and with respect to the rights, integrity, and privacy of patients. All consent, material/information storage, and distribution procedures have been approved by the local Ethics Committees (CEI PTV protocol no. 50/20). SARS-CoV-2-positive patients who will be offered participation in a research study will sign an informed consent prepared ad hoc and which will provide detailed information on the type of test, the implications of the genetic results and the possible psychosocial implications. As regards the participation of children in the research, consent and authorization are expected to be signed by the parents in accordance with the rules laid down by the Ethics Committee of the Bambino Gesù Hospital in Rome (<u>).</u>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.

title: Analysis of ACE2 genetic variants in 131 Italian SARS-CoV-2-positive patients
